properties.title: Create a virtual machine with a language pack

steps.name: basics
steps.label: Basics
steps.description: Create a Windows virtual machine using Azure marketplace image with specified language pack. Complete the Basics tab then Review + create to provision a virtual machine with default parameters or review each tab for full customization.

location.label: Region
location.toolTip: Choose the Azure region that's right for you. Not all VM sizes are available in all regions.

elements.name: vmName
elements.label: Virtual machine name
elements.toolTip: Virtual machines in Azure have two distinct names: virtual machine name used as the Azure resource identifier, and in guest host name. When you create a VM in the portal, the same name is used for both the virtual machine name and the host name. The virtual machine name cannot be changed after the VM is created. You can change the host name when you log into the virtual machine.

validations.message: Virtual machine names can contain all alphanumeric characters and special character '-', also, not begin with '-' and not end with '-'.
Virtual machine name cannot contain only numbers.
Virtual machine name must be between 1 and 15 characters long.

elements.name: vmImageSku
elements.label: Image
elements.toolTip: Choose the base operating system for the virtual machine.

elements.name: vmSize
elements.label: Size
elements.toolTip: Select a VM size to support the workload that you want to run. The size that you choose then determines factors such as processing power, memory, and storage capacity. [Learn more about Virtual Machine sizes](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=2079859)

elements.name: adminUserName
elements.label: Username
elements.toolTip: The administrator username for the virtual machine.

toolTip.password: The administrator password for the virtual machine.

elements.name: language
elements.label: Language
elements.toolTip: The operating system's language and region for the virtual machine.

elements.name: languageCapability
elements.label: Language capability
elements.toolTip: The range of the language capability packages to be installed to the virtual machine.

allowedValues.label: Essentials only
allowedValues.description: Install only essential language capability packages such as Basic, Fonts and OCR.

allowedValues.label: All
allowedValues.description: Install all language capability packages such as Basic, Fonts, OCR, Handwriting, Speech and TextToSpeech.

elements.name: timeZone
elements.label: Time zone
elements.toolTip: The time zone for the virtual machine.

allowedValues.label: (UTC-04:00) Georgetown, La Paz, Manaus, San Juan
(UTC+01:00) Amsterdam, Berlin, Bern, Rome, Stockholm, Vienna
(UTC+02:00) Helsinki, Kyiv, Riga, Sofia, Tallinn, Vilnius

elements.name: copyToDefaultUserAccount
elements.label: Apply the same settings to the default user account
elements.toolTip: If checked, apply language & region settings that you choose to the default user account too.

steps.name: details
steps.label: Disk & networking
steps.description: Define disk configuration and network connectivity for your virtual machine.

elements.name: osDiskType
elements.label: OS disk type
elements.toolTip: You can choose between Azure managed disks types to support your workload or scenario. [Learn more about managed disk types](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=2077396)

allowedValues.label: Premium SSD (LRS)
allowedValues.description: Best for production and performance sensitive workloads. Locally-redundant storage (data is replicated within a single datacenter).

allowedValues.label: Standard SSD (LRS)
allowedValues.description: Best for web servers, lightly used enterprise applications and dev/test. Locally-redundant storage (data is replicated within a single datacenter).

allowedValues.label: Standard HDD (LRS)
allowedValues.description: Best for backup, non-critical, and infrequent access. Locally-redundant storage (data is replicated within a single datacenter).

elements.name: deleteOsDiskWithVm
elements.label: Delete with VM
elements.toolTip: Disks persist independently from the virtual machine. You can choose to automatically delete a disk when the associated virtual machine is deleted. [Learn more](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=2161664)

toolTip.virtualNetwork: Virtual networks are logically isolated from each other in Azure. You can configure their IP address ranges, subnets, route tables, gateways, and security settings, much like a traditional network in your data center. Virtual machines in the same virtual network can access each other by default.
toolTip.subnets: A subnet is a range of IP addresses in your virtual network, which can be used to isolate virtual machines from each other or from the Internet.

elements.name: usePublicIpAddress
elements.label: Use public IP address
elements.toolTip: Use a public IP address if you want to communicate with the virtual machine from outside the virtual network.

elements.name: deletePublicIpAddressWithVm
elements.label: Delete public IP address and network interface when VM is deleted
elements.toolTip: Public IP addresses and network interfaces persist independently from the virtual machine. You can choose to automatically delete the public IP address and network interface when the associated virtual machine is deleted. [Learn more](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=2161664)

elements.name: deleteNetworkInterfaceWithVm
elements.label: Delete network interface when VM is deleted
elements.toolTip: Network interfaces persist independently from the virtual machine. You can choose to automatically delete the network interface when the associated virtual machine is deleted. [Learn more](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=2161664)
